djangotailoring.accounts.forms¶

A set of forms are provided for helping with authentication and user creation. When a user has an incomplete account (that is, without either a valid email address or a valid password), they may authenticate using just an access code. If they have a valid account, they may use their email address and chosen password to do the job. Both authentication forms are provided. Additionally, a User completion form is available to help the user from make a valid user account.

Authentication Forms¶

Both forms are drop-in replacements for the login form of the built-in view django.contrib.auth.views.login()

class djangotailoring.accounts.forms.EmailAuthenticationForm(request=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Provides users with a login form with two fields:

  • “Email Address” (email)
  • “Password” (password)

This is useful in conjunction with djangotailoring.accounts.backends.EmailModelBackend

class djangotailoring.accounts.forms.AccessCodeForm(request=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Provides users with a login form with one field:

  • “Access Code” (accesscode)

This is useful in conjunction with djangotailoring.accounts.backends.AccessCodeBackend and the like.

User Account Completion Forms¶

class djangotailoring.accounts.forms.CompleteUserForm(user, *args, **kwargs)¶
Parameters:user (a django.contrib.auth User instance) – the user to update.

Provides users with a form with three fields:

  • “Email Address” (email)
  • “Password” (password1)
  • “Password” (again) (password2)

This validates that a user’s email address is legitimate and unique, and has input two matching passwords.

save(self[, commit=True])¶
Parameters:commit (a boolean) – instructs
Return type:a django.contrib.auth User instance

Assigns the email address and password to the user. commit controls whether the user is saved, or returned unsaved.
